questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
Your company has an Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) tenant named contoso.com that contains several Windows 10 devices.
When you join new Windows 10 devices to contoso.com, users are prompted to set up a four-digit pin.
You need to ensure that the users are prompted to set up a six-digit pin when they join the Windows 10 devices to contoso.com.
Solution: From the Azure Active Directory admin center, you configure automatic mobile device management (MDM) enrollment. From the Endpoint Manager admin center, you configure the Windows Hello for Business enrollment options.
Does this meet the goal?

discussion.content: A is correct
Correct answer!

questions.answer_description:
Hello for Business is an alternative sign-in method that uses Active Directory or an Azure Active Directory account to replace a password, smart card, or a virtual smart card. It lets you use a user gesture to sign in, instead of a password. A user gesture might be a PIN, biometric authentication such as Windows Hello, or an external device such as a fingerprint reader.
Intune integrates with Hello for Business in two ways:
✑ An Intune policy can be created under Device enrollment. This policy targets the entire organization (tenant-wide). It supports the Windows AutoPilot out-of- box-experience (OOBE) and is applied when a device enrolls.
✑ An identity protection profile can be created under Device configuration. This profile targets assigned users and devices, and is applied during check-in.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/intune/protect/windows-hello

comments.content:
April 2022. Still on Windows Event Viewer under Microsoft/Windows/Windows Defender/Operational
Source:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/security/defender-endpoint/evaluate-controlled-folder-access?view=o365-worldwide#review-controlled-folder-access-events-in-windows-event-viewer

Endpoint Account protection (Preview) policies help protect user credential by using technology such as Windows Hello for Business and Credential Guard. It has nothing to do with Event Viewer.

discussion.content: Now it has been moved to Intune > EndpointSecurity > Account protection. As on writing - 16th Oct 2021 it is in Preview

Selected Answer: A
Controlled folder access events appear in Windows Event Viewer: Microsoft/Windows/Windows Defender/Operational folder.

Event ID Description
5007 Event when settings are changed
1124 Audited controlled folder access event
1123 Blocked controlled folder access event

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/security/defender-endpoint/evaluate-controlled-folder-access?view=o365-worldwide

questions.question_text:
You enable controlled folder access in audit mode for several computers that run Windows 10.
You need to review the events audited by controlled folder access.
Which Event Viewer log should you view?

questions.answer_description:
Box 1: Endpoint analytics -
Endpoint analytics has the following three items are central to understanding each of the reports:

Scores -

Baselines -

Insights and recommendations -

Box 2: 5 -
A status of insufficient data means you don't have enough devices reporting to provide a meaningful score. Currently, at least five devices are required.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/analytics/scores#understanding-scores
questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have a Microsoft 365 tenant that uses Microsoft Intune.
From the Microsoft Endpoint Manager admin center, you plan to create a baseline to monitor the Startup score and the App reliability score of enrolled Windows
10 devices.
You need to identify which tool to use to create the baseline and the minimum number of devices required to create the baseline.
What should you identify? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

comments.content:
five devices.
"A status of insufficient data means you don't have enough devices reporting to provide a meaningful score. Currently, at least five devices are required."
Ref: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/analytics/scores#understanding-scores

I CHECKED in my tenant too. When you click on Reports > Endpoint analytics | Settings > Baseline it says 10 devices to CREATE a baseline. But on the link provided dated 04/05/2022, it says 5 devices to REPORT. Microsoft kills me. So, I vote:
-Endpoint Analytics
-10 (to create)

I just checked this in Endpoint Manager (Reports>Endpoint Analytics>Settings>Baseline).
It clearly states, that 10 (TEN) devices are necessary to CREATE a baseline. (After that, it seems that 5 devices need to report to access the data, but that is not what the question is about!)

discussion.content:
Minimum number of devices: 10

There also needs to be a minimum of 10 x Windows 10 devices enrolled into Intune (Azure AD joined or Co-managed/Hybrid joined) in your tenant before Endpoint Analytics will start to collect data, and it will take up to 72 hours (from experience) for the tenant to report on what it has found.

Source: https://iamitgeek.com/2021/08/23/microsoft-endpoint-analytics-overview/

1. Endpoint Analytics 
2. Minimum number of Devices is 5

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/analytics/enroll-intune#:~:text=We%20currently%20require%20at%20least%20five%20devices.

Endpoint Analytics
10 Devices
5 devices required
Answer is correct according to the link provided in the solution.

1. Endpoint Analytics 
2. Minimum number of devices : 5
A status of insufficient data means you don't have enough devices reporting to provide a meaningful score. Currently, at least five devices are required.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/analytics/scores#understanding-scores

comments.content: Looking at the reference sometimes is not enough. Specially when it says 5 devices to "report", not to "create" a baseline. You have to TEST in your own test tenant. There you're not allowed to "create" a baseline if you don't have at minimum 10 devices.

discussion.content: Correct answer provided, look at the reference.
Answer is correct.

questions.question_text:
Your company has a Microsoft 365 tenant.
Users sign in to Windows 10 devices by using their Microsoft 365 account.
On a computer, you open Sync your settings as shown in the exhibit. (Click the Exhibit tab.)
//IMG//

You need to set Sync settings to On.
What should you do?
questions.answer_description:
Enterprise State Roaming provides users with a unified experience across their Windows devices and reduces the time needed for configuring a new device.
Enterprise State Roaming operates similar to the standard consumer settings sync that was first introduced in Windows 8.
Note: To enable Enterprise State Roaming
1. Sign in to the Azure portal.
2. Browse to Azure Active Directory > Devices > Enterprise State Roaming.
3. Select Users may sync settings and app data across devices.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/devices/enterprise-state-roaming-enable

discussion.content: D is the answer. I confirmed in lab.

comments.content:

discussion.content: Seems correct

comments.content:
Y- for Enterprise
Y- for Pro or Enterprise
N- for Pro

Answers provided are correct.

discussion.content: Tested, Y, Y, N.
Answer is YNY see also https://www.examtopics.com/discussions/microsoft/view/81665-exam-md-100-topic-5-question-97-discussion/

According to this article shared by RodrigoT the answers are:

Y - For Windows 10 Enterprise 1809 or higher. Or Windows 11 Enterprise
N - Only for Windows 10 Enterprise 1709 or higher. Or Windows 11 Enterprise
Y - For Windows 10 Enterprise OR Pro 1803 and higher. And Windows 11 Enterprise or Pro

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/security/threat-protection/microsoft-defender-application-guard/configure-md-app-guard#application-specific-settings

after doing some searching for comuter 2 and 3
computer 1: Yes
computer 2: No , basically no support for pro check link: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/client-management/mdm/windowsdefenderapplicationguard-csp#clipboardsettings
Computer3:Yes, supports latest version of Ent & pro check the link: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/client-management/mdm/windowsdefenderapplicationguard-csp#clipboardsettings; 
with that being said, if you go to admx help site it says Supported on: Windows 10 Enterprise, Windows 10 Education, or later for both policies.
that is a strange inconsistency of information from Microsoft. well, at least guaranteeing one point.
see the links: https://admx.help/?Category=Windows_10_2016&Policy=Microsoft.Policies.AppHVSI::AppHVSI_AllowPersistence

https://admx.help/?Category=Windows_10_2016&Policy=Microsoft.Policies.AppHVSI::AppHVSI_AllowPersistence
Windows 10 1803 is out of support - May 11th 2021. This question will possibly not be asked or will be Y Y Y.
Why not YYY?

comments.content: Same as above, Y, N, Y

Actually Allow files to download to host operating system supports for both 10 Enterprise and Pro 1803 or higher 
But clipboard settings only supported on Win 10 Enterprise 1709 or higher
So Y N Y
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/security/threat-protection/microsoft-defender-application-guard/configure-md-app-guard#application-specific-settings

Okay, I already know. "Allow files" only works in Windows 10 Enterpise, and in the scenario we have Windows 10 Pro. 
All answers are correct.
Allow files to download to host operating system Windows 10 Enterprise, 1803 or higher

Windows 10 Enterprise or Pro, 1803 or higher
Windows 11 Enterprise or Pro ,So Pro can do it.
